captions.text: - Have you ever felt that sheer panic
when you think that you've been left out
excluded, alientated?

You're scrolling the old
Instagram, as one does,
and you come across a picture of friends.
They're so cute, they're smiling,

oh my God, they look like
they're having so much fun.
Wait, where is this?
Are they at a club? Or a circus?
Why wasn't I invited?
Hello, old insecurities,

care to jump to the
worst conclusion with me?
Are they tired of me?
Did I say something?
Are they just pretending to like me?
Maybe there's a logical reason for this.

They were planning a
surprise party for me,
but it's not anywhere near my birthday.

You like the picture, pretending
it doesn't bother you.
You're dreading seeing them again.
Should you even bring it up?

You decide to play it
cool, like you don't care.
You try and gather intel, but casually.
So, what'd you do the other night?

Oh yeah, just hung out
with the gang, yeah?
Sounds cool, sounds cool.
You're waiting for some epic apology,

like, "Oh my God, I totally
forgot to invite you,

"I'm so sorry." Or even,
"Oh, I didn't really think
"it was your thing."
Anything would be fine.

Or maybe you didn't want to
go out to whatever it was,
but the invitation would have made you
feel wanted, appreciated.
The frustration builds up until
it's impeding your every thought.
You can't even enjoy lunch.

And then that anxiety
turns into resentment,
but it shouldn't.
Because them leaving you out,
it probably wasn't on purpose.
But, the rough truth is,

we're only the center of
our own individual worlds,
and everyone's scared of being left out.

comments.text:
For like 6 months in middle school the people who were my friends decided 
to become totally bitches (as in greeting me with "Fuck you!" like the 
average person would say "Good morning!" or something) after one of our 
friends left the school over Christmas. I didn't have anyone else to go to, 
and I felt trapped. Then I met some other girls who were nice,but it was 
really hard to cut ties with the girl in the bitch group who had been my 
friend for the previous 2 years and was to only one in the clique who still 
enjoyed my company.
Most girls who were in the bitch clique were in most of my classes, so I 
saw her quite frequently, but also the rest of the clan, too.
My friends who were actual friends had known each other for quite a while 
longer, so I was in a "testing the water" period for about a month. During 
that month, I still felt kind of lonely, so I got into Pokémon and soon my 
best friend in the whole, wide world was a Caterpie and not a person.
My life sucked back then.﻿

comments.text:
I feel this almost all the time, but I think I cause it on myself. All my 
friends will be hanging out at someone house and then they'll call me to 
come over, but then I get scared since there are a lot of people there 
(including people who are 'friends of friends') and its scares me a lot. I 
tell them I don't feel like going out and they say it's fine but after an 
hour or so, I feel a lot of regret and sadness over it and it bothers me so 
much. I'm just scared of people, really. My mom is constantly telling me 
that I need to go out more, be more social, stop being inside so much, go 
to more of these 'get together's' but I can't, I just can't convince myself 
to. Am I the only one who's like this?﻿

comments.text:
It kills me every time I go on Instagram and see a post of people who claim 
to care about me, post pictures of them hanging out with their friends. 
This girl Karlie I know knows I like someone who they're best friends with, 
and the guy and I are friends...and she started saying in front of me, as 
if I wasn't there, "Hey Caleb, WANNA hang soon with me, you, Declan, and 
Sam? (I like Declan) And I sat there, finishing my project, and crying. She 
didn't even notice. She just sat there laughing with her friends while I 
cried. I was dying inside. She always says stuff like: "Oh don't worry I'm 
here for you! I'll be here, and you shouldn't be sad." And then she leaves 
me to go with her friends...ugh. There's 15 other people who do this to me 
and break my heart.﻿

comments.text:
I went to college in San Francisco, but I live out in the suburbs. So most 
of my friends from college are urbanites who are always finding interesting 
stuff to do in the city, at just about any hour of the day. Meanwhile, I'm 
stuck in a crappy town miles and miles away, and I feel like it's always me 
who has to make an effort to meet up with them. Occasionally I'll get 
invited, but those are for things like birthdays. It gets me really 
depressed.﻿
